awd_titl_txt: Regulation of the Bacillus Subtilis TRP Genes by an RNA Binding Protein
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual Merit: The first step to express genes in all cells is to copy the information stored in the DNA genome into an intermediate molecule of RNA.  This process is called transcription and is highly regulated in all organisms.  Transcription starts at a location on the DNA called a promoter and finishes at a terminator.  While a great deal is known about the process of initiation and how it is regulated, relatively less is known about the process of termination.  In many bacteria, expression of genes is modulated by a process called attenuation, which prematurely terminates transcription prior to transcription of the protein coding portion of the gene.  This project will examine one such attenuation mechanism that controls expression of the genes involved in the synthesis of the amino acid tryptophan (trp) in a bacterium called Bacillus subtilis.  Attenuation control of these genes is modulated by a protein called TRAP.  When the bacterial cell has sufficient tryptophan, TRAP binds to a specific site on the trp RNA and causes transcription to terminate prior to the protein coding region of the gene(s).  Previous work suggested that the mechanism by which TRAP functions is to alter the structure of the RNA.  However, recent studies have shown that just altering the RNA structure is not sufficient to cause transcription to terminate in these genes. Hence, TRAP plays an additional role in causing termination. One of the goals of this project is to define the role that TRAP plays in controlling transcription.  Complete elucidation of how TRAP influences RNA polymerase (the transcription enzyme) to terminate will make an important and unique contribution to our understanding of the fundamental process of transcription in bacteria.  A second goal of the project is to study regulation of the TRAP protein by another protein called Anti-TRAP.  Anti-TRAP inhibits the attenuation activity of TRAP by  binding to TRAP and preventing it from binding to RNA.  Both TRAP and Anti-TRAP are multimeric proteins, composed of identical subunits (11 for TRAP and 3 for Anti-TRAP).  Recent studies have shown that multiple Anti-TRAP trimers can bind to the TRAP 11-mer. However the significance of this is not clear.   This project will evaluate how many Anti-TRAP trimers must bind to TRAP to prevent it from binding RNA and how perturbations of these protein-protein interactions affect regulation. 

Broader impacts: Graduate students and undergraduates, including women and underrepresented minority students will participate in these studies. The University at Buffalo is a very diverse campus, providing the opportunity to mentor minority students.  The research for this project will be conducted by four women students, one of whom is African American and one who is Hispanic.  Travel funds will be used to enable students to present talks and posters at national meetings.  Findings from this work will be included in lectures in our undergraduate Genetics course, as well as in our graduate Advanced Molecular Genetics course.  Prior work on this project has already made its way into several text books used in undergraduate and graduate courses.  There is every reason to believe that the results from this project will do the same.

Intellectual Merit

The goal of this project was to understand the mechanisms involved in regulating expression of the genes involved in biosynthesis of the amino acid tryptophan (trp genes) in the bacterium Bacillus subtilis.  When tryptophan levels in the cell are low the genes are expressed in order to make the proteins to synthesize tryptophan, but when the cells have sufficient tryptophan the genes are not expressed. We had previously shown that a protein called TRAP (trp RNA binding attenuation protein) controls these genes in response to changes in the levels of tryptophan in the cells. TRAP is an unusual protein composed of 11 identical subunits arranged in a ring (See attached figure).  Each pair of adjacent subunits can bind one tryptophan molecule and this binding activates TRAP to bind a specific sequence in RNA.  A model for regula­tion of these genes (See Attached Figure) was first proposed in 1988 and remained little changed until the work supported by this grant.  In this model, transcription of the DNA encoding the trp genes into RNA is controlled by two alterna­tive RNA structures in a region upstream of the trp genes. In limiting tryptophan an anti-terminator RNA structure forms and al­lows transcription of the genes. In excess trypto­phan TRAP binding induces for­mation of an alternative termina­tor (attenua­tor) RNA structure, which halts transcription prior to the trp genes. Our work supported by this grant provided evidence that this model is incomplete.  Specifically we showed that simply changing the RNA structure to favor the attenuator is not sufficient to cause efficient transcription termination.  Our studies provide evidence for a new function of TRAP in signaling the transcribing RNA polymerase to halt though a new mechanism that has not previously been seen in any system.

The activity of TRAP is controlled both by the levels of the amino acid tryptophan in the cell and by another small antagonist protein called Anti-TRAP (AT). AT is a trimeric protein that binds to TRAP and prevents TRAP from binding RNA thereby increasing expression of the trp genes. During the course of this grant we showed that AT prevents TRAP-mediated termination by induc­ing dissociation of TRAP from the nascent RNA.  We also showed that AT interacts with TRAP through a novel mechanism in which each AT trimer can interact with several TRAP 11mers to form large heteromeric complexes in which TRAP does not bind RNA (See attached Figure). These studies revealed a new mechanism for gene regulation.

The work performed under this grant resulted in 11 publications including one book chapter and 10 articles scientific journals.

 

Broader Impacts

This grant supported three female PhD students who all obtained their degrees during the course of the grant.  Two are currently in post-doctoral positions and the third is currently a junior faculty member at a public university in New York. In addition three technicians, two of which are female were supported on this grant. The male technician is currently in medical school here at the Univ. of Buffalo. One of the two females has moved on to a PhD program at Ohio State Univ. and the other, who is Hispanic, is working at a local hospital. Finally 5 undergraduate students worked on this project.  One of these is African American, and two are female.  Two of these have since entered into medical school programs.
